reasoning:
The critique targets the essay’s “value as the product of factors” model, which is a meaningful supporting pillar for the Section 2 story about fragility and the illustrative quantitative skew (the N-dimensions graph), but it is not the sole or necessary support for the overall “no easy eutopia” conclusion (which also leans heavily on the broader catalogue of moral-catastrophe examples and the Section 3 analysis of ‘fussy’ moral views). So centrality is moderate.

On strength: the critique effectively undercuts the inference from “single flaws can matter a lot” to “multiplicative aggregation is a good/general model,” by noting multiplicativity is a substantive normative assumption and that many plausible theories use different structures (additive, constraints/thresholds, lexical priorities) under which ‘mostly-great’ outcomes needn’t be so rare. This substantially weakens the product-model-based quantitative punchline. However, it doesn’t show the product model is wrong (it could still be a reasonable toy model), and it doesn’t address other routes the essay gives to “fussiness,” so it only partially damages the overall position.

Correctness is high: the mathematical/structural point about what multiplicativity implies and the limited evidential force of the N-dim toy model outside that family are basically right. Clarity is high and it stays tightly on one issue with little dead weight.
title: Multiplicative aggregation is a normative assumption that exaggerates eutopian fragility
